channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [WFLY-5290] Adding JGroups stack hangs the server
item.description: Adding new JGroups stack with randomly chosen (non existing) socket binding name results in web console freeze.
item.summary: Adding JGroups stack hangs the server

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Harald Pehl can you document your findings why the consoles freezes (if at all)? Whatever error we need to handle, it should not result in an unresponsive interface.

This composite operation puts 100% load on the server. This gives the impression that the console freezes.

{
 
    "address" => [],
 
    "operation" => "composite",
 
    "steps" => [
 
        {
 
            "address" => [
 
                ("profile" => "full-ha"),
 
                ("subsystem" => "jgroups"),
 
                ("stack" => "foo-stack")
 
            ],
 
            "operation" => "add"
 
        },
 
        {
 
            "address" => [
 
                ("profile" => "full-ha"),
 
                ("subsystem" => "jgroups"),
 
                ("stack" => "foo-stack"),
 
                ("transport" => "TRANSPORT")
 
            ],
 
            "type" => "UDP",
 
            "socket-binding" => "foo-socket-binding",
 
            "operation" => "add"
 
        },
 
        {
 
            "address" => [
 
                ("profile" => "full-ha"),
 
                ("subsystem" => "jgroups"),
 
                ("stack" => "foo-stack"),
 
                ("protocol" => "UNICAST2")
 
            ],
 
            "operation" => "add",
 
            "socket-binding" => "another-socket-binding"
 
        }
 
    ]
 
}

The composite operation is assembled and executed in org.jboss.as.console.client.shared.subsys.jgroups.JGroupsPresenter#onCreateStack
Can this be reproduced using the CLI? In that case I would delegate it to Brian Stansberry

Can be reproduced using the CLI.

This op puts the load on the server

/profile=full-ha/subsystem=jgroups/stack=foo/transport=TRANSPORT:add(type=UDP,socket-binding=foo)

It makes no difference if I use an existing socker-binding

/profile=full-ha/subsystem=jgroups/stack=foo/transport=TRANSPORT:add(type=UDP,socket-binding=jgroups-udp)

Brian Stansberry Can you take a look?

I moved this to WFCORE as a preliminary look doesn't show anything particular to clustering happening.

Perhaps it has something to do with the alias resource being addressed; perhaps something else.

This sounds a lot like https://issues.jboss.org/browse/WFCORE-955
EDIT: I could reproduce on master with ^^ merged so it isn't that

This seems to be because it is looping in the aliases. What happens when executing the CLI command is

1) This operation comes in:

{
 
    "address" => [
 
        ("profile" => "full-ha"),
 
        ("subsystem" => "jgroups"),
 
        ("stack" => "foo"),
 
        ("transport" => "TRANSPORT")
 
    ],
 
    "operation" => "read-operation-description",
 
    "name" => "add",
 
    "operation-headers" => {
 
        "caller-type" => "user",
 
        "access-mechanism" => "NATIVE"
 
    }
 
}

2) It ends up in AliasStepHandler where the original address is:

[
 
    ("profile" => "full-ha"),
 
    ("subsystem" => "jgroups"),
 
    ("stack" => "foo"),
 
    ("transport" => "TRANSPORT")
 
]

This address is then transformed to the same, so that the 'mapped' variable in AliasStepHandler contains

[
 
    ("profile" => "full-ha"),
 
    ("subsystem" => "jgroups"),
 
    ("stack" => "foo"),
 
    ("transport" => "TRANSPORT")
 
]

3) AliasStepHandler then replaces the address in the operation with exactly the same, so it adds exactly the same operation as from 1) and we have the loop.

A wild guess is that it is this PR https://github.com/wildfly/wildfly/pull/7911 from Paul Ferraro merged last week (unless this was already in EAP)
Paul Ferraro Given Kabir's comment above, I'm assigning this back to you.

Here is the output of the variables at

registerAlias():462, AbstractResourceRegistration {org.jboss.as.controller.registry}
 
register():209, TransportResourceDefinition {org.jboss.as.clustering.jgroups.subsystem}
 
register():216, StackResourceDefinition {org.jboss.as.clustering.jgroups.subsystem}
 
register():122, JGroupsSubsystemResourceDefinition {org.jboss.as.clustering.jgroups.subsystem}
 
initialize():58, JGroupsExtension {org.jboss.as.clustering.jgroups.subsystem}
 
initializeExtension():131, ExtensionAddHandler {org.jboss.as.controller.extension}
 
initializeExtension():104, ExtensionAddHandler {org.jboss.as.controller.extension}


this = {ConcreteResourceRegistration@5356} 
address = {PathElement@5414} ""transport" => "TRANSPORT""
 
alias = {SimpleAliasEntry@5415} 
 target = {ConcreteResourceRegistration@5357} 
 aliasAddress = {PathAddress@5459} "[\n    ("profile" => "*"),\n    ("subsystem" => "jgroups"),\n    ("stack" => "*"),\n    ("transport" => "TRANSPORT")\n]"
 
 targetAddress = {PathAddress@5418} "[\n    ("profile" => "*"),\n    ("subsystem" => "jgroups"),\n    ("stack" => "*"),\n    ("transport" => "*")\n]"
 
rootInvocation = {AbstractResourceRegistration$RootInvocation@5416} 
root = {ConcreteResourceRegistration@5267} 
myaddr = {PathAddress@5417} "[\n    ("profile" => "*"),\n    ("subsystem" => "jgroups"),\n    ("stack" => "*")\n]"
 
targetAddress = {PathAddress@5418} "[\n    ("profile" => "*"),\n    ("subsystem" => "jgroups"),\n    ("stack" => "*"),\n    ("transport" => "*")\n]"
 
target = {ConcreteResourceRegistration@5357}

Kabir Khan Brian Stansberry I'm convinced that this is not a clustering specific issue but rather a general issue with resource aliases and add operations. It seems that the alias is not resolving because no such attribute exists at the target address - and there won't be, because this is an add operation.
Paul Ferraro Can you point to a particular place in the code? Your last comment reads like you've found one.

I was going to add a test to check the theory, but it seems that AliasResourceTestCase.testAliasedResourceAndAttributeReadWriteFromAliased() already does an add for /aliased=model (in addCore()), which then gets translated to /core=model, and the add succeeds.

It has been a while since I last looked, but the problem to me appears to be in SimpleAliasEntry. I also see this infinite loop using standalone-ha.xml when doing /subsystem=jgroups/stack=tcp/transport=TRANSPORT:read-resource. The address returned by AliasStepHandler's call to SimpleAliasEntry.convertToTargetAddress() is the same as what is passed in. AliasStepHandler then adds a step for the 'real address'. However, since that 'real address' is still the original alias address, that step then resolves to AliasStepHandler again, and on and on it goes.

https://github.com/wildfly/wildfly/blob/master/clustering/common/src/main/java/org/jboss/as/clustering/controller/SimpleAliasEntry.java#L51 probably explains it. The target address is a wildcard address transport=TRANSPORT, and it takes the 'transport' key from the target address, and adds the 'TRANSPORT' value from the operation/alias address. You probably want a different path conversion for this occurrence.

[17:58] Kabir Khan: @PaulFerraro For https://issues.jboss.org/browse/WFLY-5290, what should the transport=TRANSPORT alias become?
[17:59] Paul Ferraro: @KabirKhan it becomes transport=*
[18:00] Kabir Khan: @PaulFerraro That can't map properly, it needs to map onto one resource
[18:00] Paul Ferraro: e.g. transport=TRANSPORT,type=UDP becomes transport=UDP
[18:00] Kabir Khan: ok, I see
in that case I can try to take a look
[18:01] Paul Ferraro: so - it needs more context than just the address
[18:01] Kabir Khan: and let me guess, that is not available at the moment from AliasEntry
[18:01] Paul Ferraro: right
Assigned back to Paul since the fix for this will be in WFCORE

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
1. Run Wildfly in domain mode
  2. Navigate to JGroups stack table in web console: Configuration -> Profiles -> full-ha -> JGroups and click on View
  3. Click on Add button
  4. Fill form in wizard
    1. Fill random name
    2. Choose UDP transport
    3. Fill random socket binding (e.g. asdfasdf)
  5. Click on Next button
  6. Fill form in wizard
    1. Select UNICAST2 name
    2. Fill random socket binding (e.g. gfsdfgsg)
    3. Click on Append button
  7. Click on Done button
  8. Web Console is now frozen (try for example click on back arrow and then selecting any subsystem)
The address of the transport changed in WF9. The workaround is to use the new address of the transport, not the legacy address, e.g. /subsystem=jgroups/stack=foo/transport=UDP
